levels.description: Learn the difference between direct array access and sequential search operations

questions.title: Understanding Array Access Patterns
questions.description: Learn the difference between direct array access and sequential search operations
questions.hint: Key concepts: 1) Direct access uses the index to jump straight to a position 2) Sequential search must check each element until finding the target
questions.review: Great work! You've learned how arrays provide instant access by index but require scanning to find specific values.

code: for i in range(len(arr)):  # O(n) - must check each

steps.comment: In an array, elements are stored one after another, with positions numbered from 0.
To find any element instantly, the computer uses the formula: starting_address + (index × element_size)
If our array starts at address 100, and each element takes 4 bytes, where would index 2 be?
Let's solve it: starting_address (100) + (index (2) × element_size (4)) = 100 + 8 = 108
Using the same formula, which index would be at address 112?
We can work backwards: (address - starting_address) ÷ element_size = (112 - 100) ÷ 4 = 3, so it's index 3
This formula is why array access is O(1): no matter how big the array is, we can calculate any element's address instantly!
Let's start with an array of numbers and understand how different access patterns work
For direct access, what happens when we access index 5?
steps.multipleChoiceExplanation: 1: Check each element, 2: Instant jump, 3: Move backward, 4: Binary search

steps.comment: Direct access is O(1) - we calculate the memory address using the index and jump straight there
Now let's try to find the value 25. We don't know its index, so we need to search
Check first element (64). Is it 25?
steps.multipleChoiceExplanation: A: Yes found it, B: Keep searching, C: Skip ahead, D: Start over

steps.comment: Move to next element (34). Is it 25?
steps.multipleChoiceExplanation: 1: Found it, 2: Keep searching, 3: Skip ahead, 4: Go back

steps.comment: Found 25! Notice how we had to check elements one by one until we found it

levels.description: Learn about linked lists and how to build them step by step.

questions.title: Understanding Circular Arrays
questions.description: Learn how circular arrays work by watching the code execute and then building your own operations
questions.hint: Key formulas: 1) For enqueue: rear = (rear + 1) % size moves rear forward, wrapping to 0 when needed. 2) For dequeue: front = (front + 1) % size moves front forward similarly. 3) Array is full when (rear + 1) % size equals front!
questions.review: Excellent! You've mastered both enqueue and dequeue operations on a circular array, including handling empty and full conditions.

steps.comment: Let's understand how CircularArray works. We start with an empty array of size 6, and two pointers: front and rear, both initialized to -1
The is_empty() method checks if the array is empty. An array is empty when front is -1
The is_full() method is more complex. Let's see how it works with some examples
What will be the result of (rear + 1) % size in this case?
Since (rear + 1) % size (5) equals front (0), this means the array is full. If they were different, it would mean we have space to add another element.
Let's try enqueuing elements. First, let's add 'A' to the empty array, where should we put A?
steps.hint: The rear pointer should be incremented to 0, since the array is empty and we're adding the first element

steps.comment: Since array was empty, front is set to 0. Rear is also set to 0 for the first element
For the next element 'B', where should we put B?

Notice how the rear pointer moved from 0 to 1 using the formula (rear + 1) % size. This is how we maintain the circular nature of the array - when we reach the end, the modulo operation wraps us back to the beginning.
Perfect! Now let's add 'C'. Rear will move to (1 + 1) % 6 = 2
Great! Let's see what happens when we reach the end. Add 'D', 'E', and 'F'
The array is now full! Notice how rear points to the last element and (rear + 1) % size equals front
Let's start the dequeue operation
First we check if the queue is empty (it's not since front is 0)
Get the value at front (A) and set that position to None
Since front (0) doesn't equal rear (5), we go to the else block
Move front forward using (front + 1) % size = (0 + 1) % 6 = 1
Now let's call dequeue() again. What happens to B?
Perfect! We dequeued B, set position 1 to None, and moved front to 2. The queue now contains [C, D, E, F]

questions.title: Understanding Queue Implementation
questions.description: Learn how queues work by watching the code execute and then building your own operations
questions.hint: Key concepts: 1) Front removes elements, Rear adds elements 2) Count tracks number of elements 3) Use modulo (%) for wraparound!
questions.review: Great job! You've mastered how queue operations work with fixed arrays, including empty and full conditions.

steps.comment: Let's understand how FixedQueue works. We start with an empty array of size 5, front at 0, rear at -1, and count at 0
The is_empty() method checks if count is 0. This tells us if there are any elements in the queue
If we add element 'A', what will is_empty() return: True(0) or False(1)?
Let's try to enqueue value 'F' when queue is full. First step: check if queue is full
Since count equals size, is_full() returns True. Will enqueue return True(1) or False(0)?
When enqueue fails, we calculate (rear + 1) % size but never assign it. What would this value be?
We never reach this line when full. The queue remains unchanged with count=5
Let's see what happens when we dequeue. First we check if queue is empty
We remove 'A' from front position and set that slot to None
Front moves to next position. What will (front + 1) % size equal?
After several dequeues, we're at the end. What happens when we dequeue 'E'?
After removing 'E', front will wrap around. What will (front + 1) % size equal?

questions.title: Deleting from a Linked List
questions.description: Learn how to remove a node from a linked list
questions.hint: To delete a node, we need to update the previous node's pointer to skip over the node we want to delete. The skipped node will no longer be part of the list.
questions.review: Well done! You've learned how to delete nodes from a linked list. By updating the pointers to skip a node, we effectively remove it from the list without breaking the chain.

code: // Skip the next node by updating the pointer

steps.comment: We start with an existing linked list
Update the pointer to skip node with value 6
Node is now removed from the list

levels.description: Learn about binary trees and how they organize data hierarchically.

questions.title: Building a Binary Tree
questions.description: Learn how to construct a basic binary tree by adding nodes as left and right children
questions.hint: Each node in a binary tree can have up to two children: a left child and a right child.
questions.review: Excellent! You've learned how to create a basic binary tree structure. Remember that each node can have at most two children.

steps.comment: First, we define our TreeNode class
Create the root node with value 10
Add the left child with value 5
Add the right child with value 15

questions.title: Inserting into a Binary Search Tree
questions.description: Learn how to insert a new node into a binary search tree while maintaining the ordering property
questions.hint: In a binary search tree, values less than a node go to the left, greater values go to the right.
questions.review: Great job! You've learned how to maintain the binary search tree property when inserting new nodes.

code: func insert(_ value: Int, into node: TreeNode) {

steps.comment: Start with an existing binary search tree
Inserting 7: Compare with root (10). Since 7 < 10, go left
7 > 5, so it becomes the right child of 5

questions.title: Tree Traversal
questions.description: Learn how to traverse a binary tree in-order
questions.hint: In-order traversal visits the left subtree, then the current node, then the right subtree.
questions.review: Excellent! You've learned how to perform an in-order traversal of a binary tree.

steps.comment: Start with a binary tree
Visit the leftmost path first
Process nodes in-order: 2, 4, 6, 8, 12
